node.title: PETSC Error - after fresh system compilation
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I have set up a new Ubuntu server and installed Moose (git commit 8664779 on 2023-05-16) and the app I use (GOLEM) without any problems just yesterday. When i want to start a test simulation which works perfectly on other machines I have but with older Moose versions (e.g. git commit d89c423 on 2023-05-04) I get an error related to PETSC.
PETSC ERROR: Incompatible vector local lengths parameter # 1 local size 76570 != parameter # 2 local size 76215
See full terminal output below.
Any idea what is causing this?
Cheers
Florian
petsc_libmesh_error.txt

My suspicion is that the change affecting you is #24018. If you could tell me the test input you're running and remind me where the golem repo is (I believe it's on github) then I could look into this for you

Thanks @lindsayad! The app that @Florian-Konrad is using is no longer on github but on an internal gitlab repo from my institution. I can add you to the members (would need an email associated to a valid git account) or Florian can rewrite the input syntax to match the old Golem version (on github) to replicate the problem.
Let me know and thanks again,
Mauro
I would prefer to not have to leave github. If that becomes too complicated we can do the gitlab repo

Thanks @mcacace and @lindsayad !
I just tested and I get the same error when using this Golem:
https://github.com/ajacquey/golem
The input I used to test is also here on github:
https://github.com/ajacquey/golem-examples/tree/main/THM_doublet
The golem GitHub repository (https://github.com/ajacquey/golem.git) has been updated (thanks @lindsayad for the support) and the input file in question runs fine with this repository.
Hi @ajacquey did you test with the current Moose ? I just reinstalled everything clean and still get the same error. I'm using your Golem from main branch, is this right?

@Florian-Konrad and @ajacquey trying to check what's the problem with the gitlab repo as well , but keep having error while rebuilding moose (undefined reference to `hit::Section::render). Once I manage to sort them out, I will try to see if I can be of any help here.
Ok, I manage to install the current Moose. I'm on it ...

So, @ajacquey I think the test passed because running on single processor. The problem only occurs if running on multiple processors.
This said, I managed to have it run while moving the declaration of the displacements vector out from the GlobalParams block.  I remembered we had a similar issue in the past, possibly being related to a different partitioning between the displaced and undisplaced mesh. @lindsayad  can it be a duplicated of https://github.com/idaholab/moose/issues/12799?
@mcacace that link gives me a 404
Sorry wrong link (https://groups.google.com/g/moose-users/c/RI-2ZEiKzms/m/1ekZbofMDgAJ)

It would be helpful if you could provide a smaller mesh for this problem, but maybe that's not possible.
The link is a good one. I expect it very well could be different partitions between undisplaced and displaced meshes
Ok #24550 seems to fix the issue for me
Thanks! Let me know if you need any assistance from my side.
Maybe just test it out and let me know if that PR works for you?
Will do. Thanks again

node.title: Slow on HPC
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I'm currently trying to run several hundred relatively small simulations on INL's Sawtooth cluster, but I'm having an issue. The study I'm doing required me to modify some source code, so I did a custom install following the instructions on mooseframework.inl.gov. But the simulations are running incredibly slowly. A simulation that takes ~4 hours on my laptop had not finished after 7 days on the cluster (1 CPU in each case).
I wanted to test whether it was my installation or my PBS job script, so I timed running the tests in moose/test/ on my laptop (1 CPU) and Sawtooth (8 CPUs). My laptop took 16 minutes and Sawtooth took 40 minutes.
Does anyone have any advice/tips to get MOOSE to run faster on Sawtooth?

Hello
I would turn on the perf_graph to see if anything obvious is being slow
Outputs/perf_graph = true.
The output of the perf_graph will be shown at the end of the simulation, so I would recommend doing a short simulation rather than the 7 day one to get some insights.
Then if there is a lot of file IO involved, it s worth running all the simulation on /scratch instead of the regular home.
Every user has a large amount of storage on scratch. The only caveat is that it s not backed up so please make sure to save your results to home every now and then.
Guillaume

sawtooth_laptop_comparison.docx
I just ran a BISON example. Here's a comparison of the perf_graph for my laptop and Sawtooth.

It does look like it's 3x slower on Sawtooth. Mostly driven by user objects. Are these bison-specific user objects?
@gambka for advice on Sawtooth performance

I just picked one at random that had perf_graph already activated:
bison/examples/2D-RZ_rodlet_10pellets/2D_discrete_finiteStrain/2D_discrete_finiteStrain.i
It doesn't have a UserObject block. They must be created by some of the actions. So there probably are some BISON-specific ones.
However, I don't think it's a problem with my BISON install specifically, because a few months ago I noticed that a MARMOT install I did was much slower than the MARMOT module.

I just picked one at random that had perf_graph already activated: bison/examples/2D-RZ_rodlet_10pellets/2D_discrete_finiteStrain/2D_discrete_finiteStrain.i It doesn't have a UserObject block. They must be created by some of the actions. So there probably are some BISON-specific ones.

It's kind of misleading since Postprocessors and VectorPostprocessors inherit from UserObjects, but there are a few true "UserObjects" that are created in that input file by the actions.

As @vanwdani has said we've seen significant slow down on sawtooth. I don't expect 7 days compared to 4 hours but we have seen slowdowns on the order of 3x on some cases with the same number of processors. For your situation where you are running multiple samples, is each sample running slowly or a certain one out of the few hundred? How are you spawning your jobs are they serially solved or are the several hundred submitted at once? Is your custom code also present in the example you ran?

It could just be the difference between processors used.  We have long
noted the difference in times when running locally on Mac, which are ARM
based, versus Sawtooth, which is an Intel Xeon.
…
On Tue, May 30, 2023 at 1:15 PM Guillaume Giudicelli < ***@***.***> wrote:
 It does look like it's 3x slower on Sawtooth. Mostly driven by user
 objects. Are these bison-specific user objects?
 @gambka <https://github.com/gambka> for advice on Sawtooth performance

 —
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#24534 (reply in thread)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIAGQHG6XKAGVS2RIUNBJN3XIZBNNANCNFSM6AAAAAAYUGHRBI>
 .
 You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.Message
 ID: ***@***.***>
@loganharbour isn't possible for @itgreenquist  to run this on an ARM cluster?

That's interesting, but I still suspect there's an issue with my installation. Is there a command to run tests or an example file using the prebuilt modules so I can compare my installation to those instead of my laptop?
module load use.moose bison if you have access to the binaries

Sure, you can do something like ./run_tests -i examples --re 2Dtm_discrete_finiteStrain to run the aforementioned example.  This will run it in parallel and test it against a common standard.  You should be able to load Bison and Moose modules with the command module load use.moose moose-apps bison.  As to your installation, are you building Petsc and Libmesh manually or are you using a package manager like Mamba?

I would still expect Sawtooth to take longer than your local machine.  As Guillaume stated, the file IO for the HPC system is a real bottleneck for speed.  As an example, you could just note the speed difference in doing a command like git status locally and remotely.  HPC is aware and always trying to fix it.
Nota bene; adding more cpus to a job can make it run slower.  There are tons of discussions here and on Slack for suggestions to match the job to cpus.

Thanks for your help @GiudGiud and @vanwdani. If it's normal for Sawtooth to run 3x slower, then the tests and examples are all working perfectly well. That means the problem is with my job script. I think it might be a memory issue. I'm going to play with the script and see if I can get these to run faster.

node.title: Question on Mortar method penetration into contact surface for contact module
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Community,
I am working on a 2d dynamic impact simulation of circle(cylinder for plane strain) onto a rectangle block. The boundary conditions is setting an initial velocity of the cylinder in positive y direction and study its response of impact on the block. Primary surface is the block bottom edge, and secondary surface is the upper 3/4 perimeter of the circle. I am using 1st order quad elements with volumetric locking.

My question is, sometimes the mortar method leads to penetration of the circle into the block.
for Mortar method the end time of the simulation

but for penalty this issue is gone for same input file and at same end time

when I plot the penetration, I think the penetration is detected correctly with a positive number in the corners. What are some possible reasons for this issue, any advice is appreciated! The input file block is
  [Mesh]
    patch_update_strategy = always
    patch_size = 10
    #partitioner = centroid
    #centroid_partitioner_direction = y
  
    [simple_mesh]
      type = FileMeshGenerator
      file = saph_al_r10_finesphquad.msh
    []
  
  
    # For NodalVariableValue to work with distributed mesh
    allow_renumbering = false
  [../]

  [Contact]
    [mechanical]
      formulation = mortar
      model = frictionless
      primary = 'block_bottom'
      secondary = 'sphere_up'
      c_normal = 1.0e3
      normalize_c=true
      mortar_dynamics = true
      newmark_beta = 0.25
      newmark_gamma = 0.5

    []
  []

for penalty the contact block is
  [Contact]
    [mechanical]
      formulation = penalty
      model = frictionless
      primary = 'block_bottom'
      secondary = 'sphere_up'
      penalty=1e3
[]
[]
@lyyc199586 I think you ran into a similar issue, right?
yes, the only difference is I am running a quasi-static one
@lindsayad

Are you actually doing a dynamics simulation? The penalty formulation will not contain any dynamics treatment, so there's a slight apples and oranges comparison here. I'd be curious if @recuero has run into this before and see if he has any suggestions.
Mortar is a weak formulation as opposed to node-face so generally speaking you may see some penetration of the secondary nodes into the primary surface. But this is definitely a bit egregious and unexpected

I have not run into this issue in particular. Edges can be an issue with Lagrange multiplier enforcement, but it shouldn't be the case for this problem. It can be related to the dynamics enforcement. There is another parameter to define, i.e. the capture tolerance. I have never run a dynamics problem with such large deformation, so I am very interested in this: @laimaster21 can you attach the entire input file and mesh that yield the problematic results?

yes, the only difference is I am running a quasi-static one

Did you try setting correct_edge_dropping in the action?

yep, this is my contact block
[Contact]
  [top_contact]
    primary = top_anvil_bottom
    secondary = top_arc
    model = frictionless
    formulation = mortar
    correct_edge_dropping = true
    c_normal = 1e4
  []
  [bottom_contact]
    primary = bottom_anvil_top
    secondary = bot_arc
    model = frictionless
    formulation = mortar
    # penalty = 1e10
    correct_edge_dropping = true
    c_normal = 1e4
  []
[]

I will collect a MWE today

    [./TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
      [all]
        add_variables = true
        strain = FINITE
        block = '35 42'
        use_automatic_differentiation = false
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz stress_yy stress_yz stress_zz
        strain_xx strain_xy strain_xz strain_yx strain_yy strain_yz strain_zx
        strain_zy strain_zz
  elastic_strain_xx  elastic_strain_xy  elastic_strain_xz  elastic_strain_yx  elastic_strain_yy
   elastic_strain_yz  elastic_strain_zx  elastic_strain_zy  elastic_strain_zz  mechanical_strain_xx
    mechanical_strain_xy  mechanical_strain_xz  mechanical_strain_yx  mechanical_strain_yy
     mechanical_strain_yz  mechanical_strain_zx  mechanical_strain_zy  mechanical_strain_zz
         vonmises_stress'
        save_in = 'saved_x saved_y'
      []
    []
  []
  
  [Kernels]

    []
    [inertia_y]

    [../]

    [./mat_sapph]

    [./crysp_hmx_fscp]
    block='42'
    type = FSCPdislo
    gtol = 1e-2
    abs_tol = 1e-6
    slip_incr_tol = 0.025
    maximum_substep_iteration = 1
    gen_random_stress_flag = true
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    nss = 12
    num_slip_sys_flowrate_props = 2 #Number of properties in a slip system
    #flowprops = '1 10 0.0  0.1'
    flowprops = '1 4 0.001e-9 0.1 5 8 0.001e-9 0.1 9 12 0.001e-9 0.1' #a0(gamma_dot0)[1/s->1/ns], xm(m exponent)
    hprops = '1.0 40e-3 40.8e-3 60.8e-3 2.5' #r, h0, tau_init, tau_sat, a
    gprops = '1 12 40e-3' # initial slip resistance
    C0 = 0.1
    C1 = 1.0
    c_l = 5.0
    G_Gruneisen = 1.97
    s_UsUp =1.34 #New MD results
    bulk_modulus_ref = 81.33 #from Al elastic tensor  K=(C11+2*C12)/3
    c = c
    temp = temperature
    reference_temperature = 300.0
    plastic_factor = 0.0
    kdamage = 1e-06
    F_name = E_elpl
    specific_heat = specific_heat
    density_name = density
    h_e = 2.0
    p = pressure
    min_line_search_step_size = 0.01
    # burgers_vector_mag=1# for debugging
    # for Al, lattice param a=0.40478nm=4.078e-4um
    # burgers_vector_mag[FCC]=a/sqrt(2)=2.8826e-4um
    burgers_vector_mag=2.8826e-4
    dslip_increment_dedge = dslip_increment_dedge
    dslip_increment_dscrew = dslip_increment_dscrew
  [../]

  [../]
      [./sumedge_pm]
          block='42'
        
          type = ParsedMaterial
          f_name = sum_edge_f
          args =  'rho_edge1 rho_edge2 rho_edge3 rho_edge4 rho_edge5 rho_edge6
          rho_edge7 rho_edge8 rho_edge9 rho_edge10 rho_edge11 rho_edge12'
        
          function = 'abs(rho_edge1) +abs(rho_edge2) +abs(rho_edge3) +abs(rho_edge4) +abs(rho_edge5) +abs(rho_edge6)
          +abs(rho_edge7) +abs(rho_edge8) +abs(rho_edge9) +abs(rho_edge10) +abs(rho_edge11) +abs(rho_edge12)'

          rho_screw7 rho_screw8 rho_screw9 rho_screw10 rho_screw11 rho_screw12'
        
          function = 'abs(rho_screw1) +abs(rho_screw2) +abs(rho_screw3) +abs(rho_screw4) +abs(rho_screw5) +abs(rho_screw6)
          +abs(rho_screw7) +abs(rho_screw8) +abs(rho_screw9) +abs(rho_screw10) +abs(rho_screw11) +abs(rho_screw12)'

node.bodyText: This is unreadable for me. See attached

The variable names are all different?
I imagine c_a is Chi_a
Is eta_s  phi_alpha ?
The advection terms seem fine for now. Once you calculate u using the Navier Stokes module, you will need to make sure that the discretization schemes for u in the NS equations and these equations are rigorously the same.
Yes, chi_A is the c_A, the concentration, and the eta_s is phi_alpha. Sorry for the misunderstanding.

node.title: Want to output the matrix of coefficients in the terminal
node.bodyText:
Hello, developers!
I am trying to know if my codes or physical equations are correct and I wanna check my matrix of coefficients, and the Jacobian matrix.
Is there any method or option to output the matrix of coefficients in the terminal? The size of the problem is not huge, just want to have a little check of my codes so I can debug.
Thank you!

Hello
You can use -ksp_view_mat to view the matrix. You can pass it on the command line or add it to the -petsc_options in the Executioner.
You should look at the petsc manual for more info on this
Guillaume
Thanks! I will look into it.

Hi @89018580 ,
I am trying to do something similar. I am looking at outputting the coefficient matrices to solve for eigenvalues in MATLAB. Were you able to output coefficient matrices for your case? I did go through the PETSc manual, and found an option -mat_view which outputs a matrix. However, not being familiar with the PETSc system, I am not able to identify what part the matrix belongs to.

-ksp_view_pmat is more reliable as it covers both NEWTON and PJFNK solve types
-mat_view will print any/all matrices right after they have been assembled. In the case of MOOSE though there is only one matrix. For NEWTON this matrix is used both for the Jacobian and preconditioner. For PJFNK it is used for the preconditioner (the Jacobian is approximated matrix-free)

Is there a way to know which part of the matrix belongs to which kernel? (corresponding term in the equation).
The problem I am trying to solve is attached below. What I am trying to output, is coefficient matrices A, B and C, as highlighted in the attached description and then use those matrices to solve for the quadratic eigenvalue. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Reference .pdf

Yea it's not clear to me what A, B, and C should be, but you can save different kernels to different matrices using the tagging system. See https://mooseframework.inl.gov/framework_development/tagging.html and the input files in the moose/test/tests/tag directory
Thanks! It worked.
awesome, great to hear!

If you are using node sets they are not oriented so any of the two nodesets that are stitched together can be used

First they seem to be read properly. I think in

interior.inp you have overlaps between bottom/top/left..._int and the line3457 (no 6?) sidesets. That's not an issue for MOOSE, as long as that's what you intended to do.
pdml.inp similarly you have overlap between bottom/top/left..._int and the line1234.

Second, they are not aligned for stitching. The two meshes are completely overlapping. As I mentioned, you need to translate them to make the interfaces match.
This answers this question:

Why are the dimensions not adding up in the horizontal axis?

I dont think the stitcher is meant to be used with overlapping meshes. That might just be the answer to this question:

Why are some boundaries recognized based on the order of stitch, and some are not.

But please let me know once you have fixed the stitiching if there are still lost boundaries
Guillaume

Ok I ll try translating on my end

ok I think I see it now.
The sidesets are preserved but not the nodesets. Or at least not with the right names.
I lost the _int nodesets, though they are still there for sidesets.
So one thing you can do right now to fix this is convert the sidesets to nodesets.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/NodeSetsFromSideSetsGenerator.html
that should recover the nodesets

Thank you. Unfortunately, the issue still happens when I try to recover the node set. I think the merger still gives precedence to the leftmost mesh and subsumed the sidesets of the second mesh.
This error the following side sets (ids) do not exist on the mesh: left_pmdl (10) is basically saying that any nodeset/sideset not in the following list is not recognized
     ID : Name
     0 : Line1
     1 : Line2
     2 : Line3
     3 : Line4
     5 : bottom_int
     6 : left_int
     7 : right_int
     8 : top_int```

node.title: Slow nonlinear convergence limit parameter
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Is there any such parameter that defines the "slowness" of convergence of nonlinear solver i.e. if nonlinear residual is not decreasing at a considerable rate then just abort and cut the time-step in half, instead of waiting until number of iteration reaches nl_max_its.
I googled a bit and found an old discussion, which is exactly what I am looking for. I wonder if it was ever implemented?
Regards.

Hello
you can do this with parsed expressions of postprocessors that contain the non linear residual.
Then this expression of the ratio or a more complex expression will need to be fed into a Terminator (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/Terminator.html) with a soft termination. This will just fail the time step without stopping the simulation
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
Yes that could do the job but not quite exactly. I tried using Terminator with execute_on = LINEAR, it does show the INFO message that terminator is causing a time step cutback by marking the current step as failed when the criteria is met but it still keeps on running that time step until the max. no of iterations are reached. What I want is to stop that time step as soon as the criteria is met and move on to the next step with half the time step.

could you please paste the Terminator here?
I think we want fail_mode = SOFT and error-level of INFO ?

Yes, that's exactly what I used:
[terminator]
  type = Terminator
  expression = 'nonlinear_residual < 1E-5'
  fail_mode = SOFT
  error_level = INFO
  execute_on = 'LINEAR'
[]

ok it seems we want a harder fail_mode here, but not "HARD" because that's going to error out the simulation.
I ll see if I can drum that up

Yes precisely!
Many thanks!

it's a little bit of a pandora's box to throw somewhat uncontrollably within a solve.
I made this branch, please feel free to try it out but I m not sure we ll be able to merge it very soon
#24463

Super!
I agree, it could be a bit tricky to throw uncontrollably, have to make sure it's safe. But I'll give it a shot.
Many thanks!!
Regards.
ok found another solution without throwing. The PR is updated. I think we should be able to add that to MOOSE
Great! this sounds better than throwing. Thanks again!!

Hello Moose experts,
I ran a transient simulation and checked my results and I noticed that it is, absolutely, physically wrong results.
In my opinion, something is wrong with simulation or numerical methods.
So, I have some questions about the Moose and FEM method.
I tried to solve two different equations below. N and V are the variables, and a, b, c, and d are the constants.

I wonder if "My equations" and  "Moose's equations" make the same results.
Is nothing wrong with this in FEM methods? Is it a natural or obvious thing?
If something is wrong, how do I avoid this in Moose?
In my opinion, solving two different equations self-consistently(when one converges and then the other one is started to solve) is a good option if it is possible in the Moose.

Hello
You have 3 (nonlinear, in [Variables]) variables. MOOSE is actually solving 3 equations.
It's not mixing equations like you're suggesting. You can verify that yourself by moving some variables from [Variables] to constant [AuxVariables] and checking the equations one by one.
I think that's the next step for you here. Making sure each equation is correct, tackling one at a time.
Please keep in mind that variable = in a kernel is both:

a way to indicate the equation that the kernel is part of
a way to indicate which variable the kernel acts on, but sometimes, for example for this object, you can make it act on another variable using a v parameter
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ADCoupledTimeDerivative.html

Guillaume

So your answer means, I am doing wrong because I want to solve the "red box two equations" in my image file but I am solving the "blue box two equations".
In order to solve the red box two equations, I have to set a kernel not
  [./Matdiff_N_del2_V]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = V
    diffusivity = eDkT_times_N
  [../]


this one, but the below one using the 'Something_new_kernel'
  [./Matdiff_N_del2_V]
    type = Something_new_kernel
    variable = N
    elec(coupled_variables) = V
    constant = eDkT
  [../]


If what I understand is correct, it makes sense!
Am I right?

is c in your equations eDkT ?
You need cN as a factor to the diffusion term.
But yes that is one kernel you'll have to change.
Thank you very much!

Hello
The problem is that you defined every single variable on both blocks.
This means that the equation for "half" of the variables' degrees of freedom is empty, it creates a singular system.
Please add block = to every variable that does not span the entire domain.
Guillaume

[Materials]
  [./Seebeck_coefficient_Sb] # [V/K] * [1/ohm cm] = [A/cm K] 
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = T
    f_name = 'Seebeck_coefficient'
    constant_names =        'C      D   uV_2_V' # SC1
    constant_expressions =  '0.0   -55 1e-6'
    function = 'C*(T+D)*uV_2_V' # [V/K]
    block = 0
    #  outputs = exodus
  []

  [./Seebeck_coefficient_TiN]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = T
    f_name = 'Seebeck_coefficient'
    constant_names =        'uV_2_V' #
    constant_expressions =  '1e-6'
    #  function = '50*uV_2_V' # [V/K] haven't found yet
    #  function = '0.9*uV_2_V' # [uV/K] haven't found yet
    function = '0.0' # [uV/K] haven't found yet
    block = '1 2'
    #  outputs = exodus
  []

  [./sigma_times_Seebeck_coefficient_Sb] # [V/K] * [1/ohm nm] = [A/nm K] 
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'eta T'
    f_name = 'sigma_times_Seebeck_coefficient'
    constant_names =        'S2       A       cminv_2_nminv crys                w     pi                C      D   uV_2_V' # w : eta interface range, 
    constant_expressions =  '66.66    10.325  1e-7          (1/9.402e-4)/4  0.1   3.141592653589    0.0   -55 1e-6'  # SC2
    function = 'C*(T+D)*uV_2_V * cminv_2_nminv * if(eta <= 0.5-w/2,crys,if(eta<0.5+w/2, 1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A))/1.2 + 0.5*(crys+1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A))/1.2)*(1.0+cos(pi * (eta-0.5+w/2)/w)),1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A))/1.2))'  # [1/(ohm*cm)]
    block = 0
  []

  [./sigma_times_Seebeck_coefficient_TiN]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = T
    f_name = 'sigma_times_Seebeck_coefficient'
    constant_names =        'cm_2_nm uV_2_V' # w : eta interface range, 
    constant_expressions =  '1e7     1e-6'
    function = '0.0' # haven't found yet
    block = '1 2'
  []

  [./thermal_conductivity_Sb]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = eta
    f_name = 'thermal_conductivity'
    constant_names =        'w      crys    amor    pi              cm_2_nm' # w : eta interface range, [W/cm K], [W/cm K]
    constant_expressions =  '0.1    1.3e-2  0.27e-2 3.141592653589  1e7'
    function = '(1/cm_2_nm) * if(eta<0.5-w/2, crys, if(eta<0.5+w/2, amor+0.5*(crys-amor)*(1.0+cos(pi*(eta-(0.5-w/2))/w)), amor))' #  [W/nm K]
    block = 0
  [../]

  [./thermal_conductivity_TiN]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = 'thermal_conductivity'
    function = '12e-9' # [W/nm K]
    block = '1 2'
  [../]

  [./specific_heat_Sb]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = eta
    f_name = 'specific_heat'
    constant_names =        'w      crys    amor    pi' # w : eta interface range, [J/g K], [J/g K]
    constant_expressions =  '0.1    0.25    0.35    3.141592653589'
    function = 'if(eta<0.5-w/2, crys, if(eta<0.5+w/2, amor+0.5*(crys-amor)*(1.0+cos(pi*(eta-(0.5-w/2))/w)), amor))' #  [J/g K]
    block = 0
  [../]

  [./specific_heat_TE]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'eta T'
    constant_names =        'A          B           C           D           E           atomic_unit' # atomic unit [g/mol], t [K/1000]
    constant_expressions =  '50.40716   0.596509    2.944759    -0.305012   -1.209679   61.8797'
    f_name = 'specific_heat'
    function = '1.2 * (1/atomic_unit) * (A+B*(T/1000)+C*(T/1000)^2+D*(T/1000)^3+E/((T/1000)^2))' # [J/mol K] to [J/g K]
    block = '1 2'
  [../]

  [./density_Sb]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'eta T'
    f_name = 'density'
    constant_names =        'w      crys  pi                cm3_2_nm3' # [g/cm^3] [g/cm^3]
    constant_expressions =  '0.1    6.684 3.141592653589    1e21'
    function = '(1/cm3_2_nm3) * if(eta<0.5-w/2, crys, if(eta<0.5+w/2, (6.902-6.486*(10^(-4))*(T-273.15))+0.5*(crys-(6.902-6.486*(10^(-4))*(T-273.15)))*(1.0+cos(pi*(eta-(0.5-w/2))/w)), (6.902-6.486*(10^(-4))*(T-273.15))))' #  [J/g K]
    block = 0
  []

  [./density_TiN]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'eta T'
    f_name = 'density'
    function = '5.4e-21' # [g/nm^3]
    block = '1 2'
  []

  [electrical_conductivity_Sb]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'eta T'
    f_name = 'electrical_conductivity'
    constant_names =        'S2       A       cm_2_nm crys              amor    w     pi' # w : eta interface range, 
    constant_expressions =  '66.66    10.325  1e7     (1/9.402e-4)/4 0.85    0.1   3.141592653589' ############ "final changed"
    function = '(1/cm_2_nm) * if(eta <= 0.5-w/2,crys,if(eta<0.5+w/2, (1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A)))/1.2 + 0.5*(crys+(1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A)))/1.2)*(1.0+cos(pi * (eta-0.5+w/2)/w)),1/(exp(S2*T^(-1/3)-A))/1.2))'  # [1/(ohm*nm)]
    block = 0
  []

  [electrical_conductivity_TiN]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = eta
    f_name = 'electrical_conductivity'
    constant_names =        'cm_2_nm' # w : eta interface range, 
    constant_expressions =  '1e7    '
    function = '(1/cm_2_nm)/200e-6' # [1/ohm cm] 6896.55
    block = '1 2'
  []

  ######## PFM ########
  [./kappa]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'kappa'
    prop_values = '${kappa}' # [eV/nm]
    block = 0
  [../]

  [./radius]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    args = 'DeltaG Interfacial_free_energy'
    f_name = r
    function = '2*Interfacial_free_energy/DeltaG'
    block = 0
  [../]

  [./free_energy]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = F
    args = 'eta DeltaG'
    function = '${W}/4*(eta^2)*(eta-1)^2+(eta^3)*(10-15*eta+6*(eta^2))*DeltaG'
    derivative_order = 2 
#    block = '0 1' # Block 1
    block = 0 
  [../]

  [./mobility]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    args = 'V_G DeltaG Interfacial_free_energy'
    f_name = L
    function = '${ksi}*V_G*(2*Interfacial_free_energy/DeltaG)/${kappa}'
    block = 0
  [../]
  
  ######## PFM END ########
[]


[BCs]
  [t_top]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = T
    value = 300
    boundary = 'top'
  []

  [V_top]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = V
    boundary = 'top'
    function = bc_func_2
  []

  [V_bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = V
    value = 0.0 # GND
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
    [./SMP]
        type = SMP
        full = true
    [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  scheme = 'bdf2'
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre      boomeramg'
  l_tol = 1e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9
  automatic_scaling = true # for line search convergence
  l_max_its = 100
  nl_max_its = 13
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = FunctionDT
    function = dts
    min_dt = 1e-14
  [../]
  petsc_options = -snes_linesearch_monitor
  end_time = 40e-9
[]

[Postprocessors]

  [./TE_function]
    type= FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = bc_func_2
  [../]


  [./T_max_time]
    type = TimeExtremeValue
    postprocessor = T_max_Sb
  [../]

  [./Resistance]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = resistance_func
  [../]

  [./Resistance_min_time]
    type = TimeExtremeValue
    value_type = min
    postprocessor = Resistance
  [../]

  [average_Jy]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = Jy
    boundary = BE_top
  []

  [Current]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = "if(average_Jy>0,average_Jy*${xmax}, -average_Jy*${xmax})"
    pp_names = average_Jy
  []

  ######## PFM ########

  [./eta_sum]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = eta
    block = 0
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  [../]

  [./X_c_PFM]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = '1-eta_sum/6218' # should be changed upon mesh change --> refine 3 version
    pp_names = 'eta_sum'
  [../]
  [./time_step]
    type=TimestepSize
  [../]

  [./TE_avg]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = V
    boundary = TE_bottom
  [../]
  [./T_max_Sb]
    type = NodalExtremeValue
    variable = T
    block = 0
    value_type = max
  [../]
  [./JouleJeat_max_Sb]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = JouleHeat_Aux
    value_type = max
    block = 0
  [../]

  ######## PFM END ########
[]
[Outputs]
  file_base = output
  csv = true
  exodus = true
  perf_graph = true
  [./console]
    type = Console
    max_rows = 10
  [../]
[]
